titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Joseph Dickinson papers, 1822-1868
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, September 2018

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Letters from Nolen and Griffith Dickinson on travels from Virginia to Missouri. Other letters of the Dickinson family are of John P. and Joseph Wright referring to the hard times and quoting the price of cotton and tobacco. In a letter of 1838, Wm. A. Dickinson suggested to Joseph Wright that they try growing Chinese mulberry trees for sale, saying that a great many people in eastern Virginia and to the north were making silk. A letter written by Hester and Lancaster of Marion, Alabama in 1854 stated that they were selling slaves very slowly since the trade in that state was very dull.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Joseph Dickinson Papers, 1822-1868, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, September 2018.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Joseph Dickinson was a resident of Franklin County, Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Letters from Nolen and Griffith Dickinson on travels from Virginia to Missouri. Other letters of the Dickinson family are of John P. and Joseph Wright referring to the hard times and quoting the price of cotton and tobacco. In a letter of 1838, Wm. A. Dickinson suggested to Joseph Wright that they try growing Chinese mulberry trees for sale, saying that a great many people in eastern Virginia and to the north were making silk. A letter written by Hester and Lancaster of Marion, Alabama in 1854 stated that they were selling slaves very slowly since the trade in that state was very dull.
